Engineers I am very interested in kind

that almost sounds dare I say slightly

where a lot of cognitive systems

the consequences of human error or of

they're quite High there's the loss of

you've been doing some interesting

do tell yeah so much of my work over the

Management in software Service delivery
and so a lot of what I've been looking

let the service kind of be degraded for

understand what's happening and the
reason why this is such an interesting

Engineers is that most large-scale

themselves and so the amount of

about operating in these same kinds of

the day software Engineers are people
they have you know similar kinds of

High consequence domains that I was
describing and one of the things that I

is the ways in which the stress and

of what's been happening within the tech

influence and impact cognitive work
particularly how it affects attention
how it affects our ability to
communicate and collaborate when there
is fear about losing a job when there is
uncertainty about when the next round of

there's been a lot of emotions after a
layoff or after a big reorg or
restructuring this can make it really
hard for people to concentrate at work
and to feel safe at work as well and so
this new sort of approach that I've been
thinking about is how do we take some of
these same kinds of models and these
same kinds of methods that we use to
understand cognitive demands and how

overload means from a cognitive
perspective and can we apply that to
these very emotionally demanding times
and it turns out that you can always
does that look like so there's three
kind of main Concepts from the field of
cognitive systems engineering that
really apply here and the first one is
around identifying boundary conditions
and when I was doing some of this
research and I was talking to software
Engineers they started telling me the
ways in which things were impacting them
and if you don't mind I would love to
share some of that with you because I
think they explain it a lot better than
I could
how am I feeling
it feels like now it's just a matter of

wasn't laid off
I got scared
you know I know there's more layoffs
coming and now I wake up every day
wondering if today's my day to get cut
so a lot of fear there and another

honestly I just want to be able to take

to work twice as much before or after
and not have everything fall totally
behind on the project like I know that
it doesn't all rest on me and I trust my

down if I'm not always there and
I can't keep that up forever
I know that I need to take the time off
and if I don't do it it's actually gonna

even a single day it feels nearly

that started to come up was the

really having the same effect
um
I do feel okay most of the time
but I've been spending time with
my friends like the friends that have
also been laid off
or are struggling with like anxiety
I know this is part of a larger cycle
and it's
supposed to end sometime soon but
unfortunately it's everywhere like
everywhere I look like LinkedIn Twitter
most of the media everyone's reporting
it
and it just it kind of feels like it's
affecting everyone
everywhere almost
so what I started to notice from these
interviews and from talking with
different folks that there was a very
real impact the emotional demands of the
current environment was having a real
cognitive impact on their ability to
concentrate their ability to focus
attention their ability to rest and
recharge to deal with the pressures of
trying to do more with less in the
current climate and I think this is a
very common feeling right now within the
industry and so I was looking at some of
the strategies and some of the models
that we use within cognitive systems
engineering and thought this actually
can be adapted to understand the
emotional demands as well so the first
strategy that I think is relevant here
is a Danish researcher named Jens
Rasmussen proposed this model for how we
think about risk and how we think risk
sort of is managed over time and he
proposed this idea that we all Opera
rate within a trade space and the
boundaries of that trade space is things
like you know cost and schedule time and
money you know are sort of hard
constraints that we have in the world
and then he proposed that the sort of
third boundary there was what he calls
the line of technical failure and what I
see as our kind of our ability to cope
it's our line of emotional failure and
what Rasmussen said is that we
constantly have these pressures within
modern work environments to then you
know save time save money and so that
kind of exerts these pressures in this
trade space and has you move closer to
your own boundary your own sort of
emotional coping boundary and obviously
Crossing those boundaries is not a good
thing and so we often put in place
counter measures to keep us away from
those boundary conditions and so the
countermeasures for things like you know
going over budget or over time is like
project check in you know it's s work
estimating and those help us to kind of
understand where we are operating in
that trade space but when it comes to
our emotional capabilities like we heard
in those examples the kind of
countermeasures that we have taking PTO
spending time with friends and family
you know being able to sort of rest and
recharge those may not have the same
effects and so we're constantly moving
closer towards the boundary and so the
trouble with boundary conditions is that
when we're operating in normal
conditions these are typically well
modeled we understand the sort of
performance of the system within normal
operating conditions but the closer we
get to the boundary the less predictable
it is so we don't know what impact the
way a failure is going to happen and we
don't know what impact that's going to
have on the rest of the system so an
example of this is you know when you
start to hear people say oh I'm
operating pretty close to the edge here
or I'm getting pushed to my limit these
are examples and these are indications
that people are kind of operating in
their emotional boundary condition is
that something that you've experienced
in your career over the time yeah
I was just thinking this sounds to me a
bit like what we would call burnout yeah
absolutely so one of the things that I
think is really great about this model
for helping us to try and understand
kind of when we're in these emotional
boundary conditions is it gives us a
sense of understanding when we're in a
drift to the boundary and so we all have
this kind of abstract idea of oh I'm
under pressure but we can start to look
for and recognize signals that we might
be getting closer to our boundary so an
example of some of those for me is when
I start pouring myself a cup of coffee
in the morning and setting it down and
then completely losing it you know in
the two minutes between when I poured it
and when I've actually sat down at my
desk it is I forget appointments more
readily I am a little bit more irritable
I'm late for things or projects start to
get you know I feel a lot of pressure to
get them produced and so when I start to
notice these signals I can recognize I'm
close to the boundary and it's less
predictable if I start to have you know
one or two more unexpected events that
show up which when we're you know doing
faster better cheaper there's typically
surprises then I may not be able to
control or to manage for those events
the same way I would under other kinds
of normal operating conditions so when
I'm in these boundary conditions I can
start to say hey it's actually really
important for my overall kind of
performance or the stability of the
system you know the continuity of the
work that my team is producing that I'm
a able to push myself back away from
that boundary can you think of examples
from your past work where you've been in
these boundary conditions oh yeah I
think one in particular where I know I
went way over the boundary condition I
ended up absolutely burned out and had
to change jobs yeah so that is a really
excellent point because what happens
when you cross the boundary is it's not
clear whether you're going to have a
collapse like you just described which
is I cannot function in this environment
anymore or whether you're going to have
you know graceful degradation or whether
you're going to have potentially what
cognitive systems engineer David wood
says graceful extensibility so before we
talk a little bit about that I just want
to kind of acknowledge what you were
saying there is that getting pushed into
the boundary conditions can often feel
like you know we have no other choices
we can't take time off as we heard you
know some of those Engineers say we
start to feel like oh if I'm not pushing
myself the rest of my team is going to
suffer around this but this is really
where I think kind of having this
language about being in the boundary
conditions and starting to try and
recognize these signals not only for
ourselves but for the people that we're
working with can help us to try and
change some of that conversation because
it implies that Crossing that boundary
you know is potentially imminent and
that that is a signal that we may have
collapsed and if you have people
collapsing and removing themselves as
you had to from the work environment
then overall the whole performance of
the system declines what can one do as
the individual but also what can leaders
do before I get to what leaders can do I
want to talk a little bit about what the
team can do together because as a system
engineer I'm usually you you know I kind
of say yeah we shouldn't focus on the
individual we shouldn't put this on you
know an already stressed out and
overworked worker to say well you just
have to be more Vigilant about how
you're doing and you have to push back
we usually say no no let's go to the
system and that is typically leadership
who has more power more Authority more
ability to influence at a systemic level
so that individuals aren't having to
push themselves so hard however given
the sort of current climate we know that
there are also some real hard
constraints around kind of how work has
to get done in this moment there's a lot
of pressure for you know many startups
many young companies for all companies
there's an economic pressure that's very
real but I want to talk a little bit
about this idea of sharing adaptive
capacity which is a really strong
principle of resilience engineering
cognitive systems engineering and
effectively sharing adaptive capacity is
thinking of about how do we think about
the actual capabilities of the system as
a whole not as a collection of
individuals per se because when we think
about ourselves as a collection of
individuals if I'm not doing okay one
day and you're actually feeling okay
that day then maybe we can lighten my
load a little bit or you know you're
able to support me to bring me back up a
little bit more without it taking away
from your capacity right your resources
in that moment and so if we start to
think about this across a whole team
that people are going to have good days
and bad days and if we can share that
then we can level out this performance
variability across the team a little bit
more and so this idea of sharing
adaptive capacity adaptive capacity is
you know Woods would describe this as
being a systems Readiness or its
potential to change how the system
currently fits so that it can continue
to Fit changing surprises anomalies and
situations and so effectively what this
means is you know if I'm not having a
great day and you're having an okay day
you know can we adjust in that smaller
time frame you know it's not you taking
over my job but it's kind of helping
each other on a more micro level so that
we can kind of smooth out that
performance curve and one of the things
that is quite useful about this idea of
sharing adaptive capacity is kind of
thinking about how it is that we
typically work together and whether
those are functional versus
dysfunctional patterns and so typical
patterns when people reach a saturation
point this is what we see from the
literature is they cope with it in four
different ways and I'll add a fifth one
but the four ways are they'll either
drop the tasks because they're too
overloaded and so dropping the tasks
means someone else on the team is going
to have to scramble to pick it up
because they have had no indication that
this is going to happen and the work
still needs to get done so someone's got
to pick it up they're going to defer it
in time so they'll say can we do this at
a later point in time which is usually
quite an effective coping strategy if I
as an individual and communicating and
coordinating with the people around me
particularly when there's work that's
very tightly sequenced or highly
interdependent they will degrade the
quality of the work and so they'll kind
of just do not as great a job on it or
they'll delegate it you know they'll
kind of recruit some other resources to
try and bring it in and so those can be
both functional and dysfunctional
patterns depending on how much
communication and coordination is
happening across the system and so the
more that we can talk about hey I'm in
my boundary conditions right now or I'm
on a pretty fast drift towards my
boundary I'm going to need to deploy one
of these strategies it gives us language
and gives us the ability to kind of ask
for capacity from our team members or
from our leaders as well I mentioned the
fifth coping strategy and that one is
one that I'm myself employing an awful
lot and it doesn't always work very well
for me and that's digging in and that's
typically gritting your teeth and
dropping your shoulder and just really
like pushing into the work and as you
described earlier with your example from
your work that only lasts for so long
and so we have to be thinking about
these other kinds of strategies that we
can use that are overall better for the
system performance so this means that on
the team we've got to really focus on
that communication having the language
but then genuinely listening to each
other and supporting each other and
possibly proactively asking each other
how are you doing yeah absolutely so
you're bringing up a really good point
there which is the earlier the
indication that there is a problem that
we're in adrift the more range of
strategies that we have or the more
options we have for how to cope with
that raid but it's also really hard to
say I'm not doing okay right and we also
think about ourselves as being like okay
well I can get through this I just need
to you know like buckle down and keep
pushing but that often doesn't work as
well as being able to say you know I'm
having a bit of a day today these are
the things I'm going to be working on
but I know I'm distracted or I'm
preoccupied or you know I'm feeling the
effects of accumulated fatigue from not
having time off and so I just kind of
want to let you know that I'm in that
zone some teams will use their slack
icons you know to be able to say I'm in
yellow or I'm in red today as a little
bit of a flag to tell others that
they're not doing that well but to your
point communicating and being a little
bit more explicit to the extent that
we're comfortable doing so and kind of
saying I think this might be one or two
days you know where I'm gonna have
degraded and I'll say quote unquote
performance because we are people not
just performance machines but being able
to kind of talk a little bit about what
some of the pressures and the demands
that we're experiencing are helps us to
reorganize that work across the team a
little bit more readily so the third you
kind of asked a little bit about like
what can leadership do and this is from
a researcher perspective this is a
really exciting idea for me and it's
about this idea of dynamic
reconfiguration and that's of the human
resources but also of like thinking
about how we organize and structure work
more readily and the reason that I find
this kind of very interesting is that
increasingly the boundaries of the
actual system what's your software
what's my software you know if it's
third party or if it's you know an
internal system those need to be quite
fluid and they need to be quite
adjustable because of the
interdependencies between different
aspects of the system and that also goes
for different functional aspects of the
team so customer support and you know
the SRE team may need to be able to
dynamically reconfigure to say hey you
know we're getting a lot of information
from our customers about a problem that
they're seeing that it's quite slow for
us to use these ticketing systems from
customer support maybe we can start to
pull them into our you know Zoom calls
when we're having an incident or someone
told me a story recently about their
company deciding to run a Super Bowl
commercial and they kind of dynamically
reconfigured within the organization and
said hey this is a very integrated you
know all company kind of approach
because what happens from the marketing
side of things and our customer support
side of things you know is going to be
very integral to the system performance
as well and so they started to work more
closely and more collaboratively across
the team so I think that in terms of
what leadership can do I think getting a
little bit more flexible in terms of how
to exchange resources from different
teams how to think about out the ways in
which things like deferred maintenance
or choices about what kind of features
to prioritize what the downstream and
Upstream implications of those are going
to have on the well-being of the team
and the amount of pressure and stress
that they feel those kind of factoring
in the emotional aspects of the software
engineering can help to alleviate some
of that pressure right even though we
are going to have to be working hard we
are still in a quite a constrained
environment and then the last thing that
I will say about this Dynamic
reconfiguration is my hope for industry
is to start thinking about
intra-organizational collaboration as
well so I talked a little bit about the
ways in which our dependencies create
this need for a different kind of
organizing that may not typically be the
standard and in my dissertation research
I actually saw a number of examples
where engineers from both sides and I
was studying incidents predominantly and
so Engineers on the vendor side and
Engineers on the client side you know
we're trying to independently debug what
was happening and some of the things
that they were asking for you know can
you run these diagnostic tests for us
we're actually exacerbating the problem
itself and so instead they began to say
okay we need to start thinking of
ourselves as one unit not as either
sides and so they would sort of break
down those walls and start to interact
more directly and these are the kinds of
changes that have to take place in order
to respond in real time to very real
issues and so my hope is that as an
industry we start to think about how
some of these barriers around how we
work together may not actually be in the
best interest of the cognitive and
emotional parts of that work for the
people involved we've been hearing more
and more recently about cognitive load
this is an early indicator I hope
ongoing conversations about emotional
load and how we deal with that there's a
